												So, RECOMMENDED. Let's just get that strait right away.TL/DR at the bottom for those who find reading painful.Do you like golf? Well, that's what this is.Do you like boobs? Well, there's more bouncing boobs than golf in this game.Do you like games you can just download and play for free? Well, game's f2p.Do you like p2w games? Well, this game's got you covered.Do you like MMOs? Well, I never thought I'd see such a thing but this is a golf game that feels just like an MMO.The graphics are good enough. They look nice, but it's not brilliant. I like them but I don't love them. I have no complaints though.The performance is okay, but not great. It has some jitters and stutters, and fps is sorta mediocre. Nothing game breaking though. It runs decent on my Alienware i-7 GeForce GTX  650 ti 6G RAM, but could run a bit better.About p2w, it's not bad, but it's kinda there. You can beef up quite a bit with real money, but it doesn't mean you can't win without spending $. The game really is more about skill than buying the Winning Putt (see what I did there?).About the Store, you can buy a lot of things with in-game gold, and other things with cash-money. Most decent clothes are buy-only.About the community, um...well, naked. The community tends to be naked...so be ready for that. :pOverall the people are nice, and we always laugh about how naked everyone is. Just a bunch of hot chicks jumping around in their bra n' panties. Sometimes you'll see guys jumping around in their whitey-tighties (yep, the game gave them whitey-tighties)...(priceless).The golf itself is about what you'd expect from a good golf game. A classic 3-click system for swining, 2-click for putting, and general aiming with the mouse to decide the ball's destination. You have weather, which adds wind or rain.You can play at night. There are days and nights, so you don't have to wait until morning to go golfing, you just golf in the  lights.Friendly matches, Ranked matches, 4-way tourneys, challenges from NPCs like simply playing a quick 3-hole on a new course or getting a good score on a 9-hole, and other ways to play and quotas to meet.You get something of a Q-school challenge, and take a test to graduate to higher levels so you can go pro.You can play on Steam or not. You don't need Steam (game has its own site), but it's an option.About bugs, currenly you'll occasionally get a frozen screen and need to restart. Not too bad, but still a thing you might deal with at some point.Customization is actually better than I expected. No boob slider though! <--There's a Chest slider that sort kinda adjusts boob size...a bit. No worries though, females get an automatic D-cup. Guys will be ripped with like 5% body fat, but you should fully expect only boy-band options. That's what your guy will look like, either a boy-band or Abercrombie type. You can't really be old n' wrinkly, so you won't be seeing anyone like that. You'll basically be in a fashion show with 1 too many people wearing the same thing. For example, you'll see a ton of girls in a pink mini-skirt with long strait hair, and all ladies get the same standard black bra n' panties.The NPCs are annoying. You need to repair your clubs a lot, and you normally do so by walking over to Evan, the repair guy who will fix your clubs, but not before flirting with your girl hard and basically suggesting...stuff. Every time. He is a♥♥♥♥♥♥And the girl at the Academy talks to you like she is a 2nd-grade English teacher (assuming you play in English). I don't have a problem with proper grammer, but jeez...you don't need to try so hard. When you first turn the game on and choose your girl, she sounds even worse. Cracks some cheesy pun and laughs like an idiot. It's like how they talk in a kid's show.Example: Remeber the hot blonde teacher from Billy Madison? Remember her pattern of speech when talking to her students? Like that, only more playful. You'll notice this the most at the beginning when going through the tutorial at the Academy.The way people talk sounds like a kid's show or 2nd-grade English class, yet everywhere you look you see girls in their undies bouncing around for no reason other than to bounce around in undies. These 2 things make for an odd combination.Winning Putt is generally a really fun golf game with tons of challenges. The mechanics and physics are pretty good. The ball basically does what you'd expect it to. The courses are nice, and the game is not too easy/not too hard, though you will have a hell of a hard time trying to get a birdie on any hole of certain courses until you level way up and get much better clubs. The way courses get harder in this game is they simply get longer and longer, making you raise your swing power up exponentially, or you simply won't get the distance to get to the green before the stroke quota has been reached for par (let alone birdie). Like an early course may have par 4's that span about 300 yards, and the next course you unlock will have par 4's at around 350 yards, and so on until low-level characters have no chance.I have plenty of fun playing, and it's a relaxing game. The AI is pretty good too. They don't really make a lot of super-stupid mistakes, nor are they totally perfect at everything. Don't underestimate a human opponent though. This game has power-up potions of sorts. Like if you got Halloween candy, eating a piece will give you +30 swing accuracy. That is quite an advantage. some things wil give you a major advantage like +80 accuracy or +40 power. The AI doesn't seem to use items like these, but human opponents will. Some of these cost Platinum, the game's equivalent of real money.TL/DRThis game has boob physics and you can play in your undies, download it.

												The 3-click Swing method has been a curse to golf games since the beginning of video games. EA Sports Tiger Woods 09' delivered a different style that worked, and since I've been adapted to as a primary method. I played golf games on consoles because it was a great way to have a few (or many) beers with friends and family while on the couch, so I've been used to the analog pull and flick style.I was hoping for a more developed swing-game when it comes to PC but it seems to be elusive to game developers of Winning Putt: Golf Online. In golf, it is all about the fluid swing. The amount of power and accuracy is determined within the swing and it is key to be smooth, perfect timing and with the utmost delicate power on impact. Adaptive swing using the mouse to follow a path from point A to point B and back to A is what I was expecting PC golf games to be using. That way the swing can be determined by power and accuracy based on mouse movements. I was let down. Looking past the sad 3-click swing method Winning Putt: Golf Online uses, the game at it's core is just a simple golf game. It has the options to flood the players with plenty of options to customize their characters, play at well designed courses, play in variable winds and weather... Beautiful graphics, and simple text-chatting. I was really hoping for a built in VOIP (Voice Over IP) to talk to other players which would really get me to play this as a primary game. But again, this is a free-to-play game which is, at its core, just a simple golf game. There is nothing about this game that drives me to want to play it more, other than sitting back, having a few beers and embarrassing players that are way more higher leveled then myself. It's not that I hate the 3-click swing method and it's tedious repetition because I'm actually deadly accurate with it. It's just an unimmersive experience using it. I'm focused on setting up the shot, then I pull away to do this mini-game, and the ball goes right where I wanted it too. The adaptive swing, or analog stick pull-flick method changed the game for me which drove me to play more-and more- and more.  I'm not sure if I'll continue to play the game, based only on the utilization of the 3-click swing method. If they design another "optional" swing method using the mouse, I'd see myself coming back to Winning Putt: Online Golf. In the end, EA Sports Rory McIlroy 2016 on console games will be my go to golf game, and Winning Putt: Golf Online is, just a simple golf game.

												I'm really on the fence about this one. I'll just say first: Yes, I reccommend trying it. But I've edited this review to be a 'no' after reaching about level 12 and seeing the f2p-paid gap increase so heavily- not only that, but there's just too many paid items. Boosts for everything. They want you to pay for a 20 minute boost for this, a 1 hour sponsorship for +5%exp, boost balls, boost bags, clubs, even a soda to restore your energy takes a crap-ton of premium-only currency. It's not just a competition gap- you're even held back playing totally alone, if you don't pay. Still fun for a couple rounds, but don't invest money into this.________________________It looks good, sounds good, and has some really nice ideas. In fact, it just feels like they almost certainly had an incomplete/cancelled fantasy MMO and decided to turn it into a golf game instead. Everything you'd expect from a generic fantasy mmo is here. Experience, leveling, skill trees, upgrades, gear, etc. Just, in this case, instead of whiffing on fireballs while you level up, you're slicing balls into deep rough when you're almost positive that the shot should've been safe. It's unique- usually with golf games, if you have the player skill you can just dominate immediately. But this game forces you (even a bit artificially) into doing poorly when you're a noob- creating an actual sense of progression. Prepare to struggle for bogeys and pars for a bit. The real downside here is, that instead of going with (what would seem to be a slam-dunk) real money only for cosmetics, the cash shop items are DEFINITELY in what would be called the "pay to win" category. Money makes you better in every single way, by leaps and bounds. Gear, skills, stats, better caddies- you're flat-out at a disadvantage versus other players if you don't pay. That being said, I'm having quite a lot of fun playing a round or two a day by myself as a Tiger Woods subsitute. Your call.

												Let me first say that I am one of those players that falls under the category of not liking actual golf but loving golf video games. You could march 20 professional golfers in front of me and short of one being Tiger Woods I wouldn't be able to recognize any of them. But anyway, ever since the NES version of golf I have been in love with golf games and curiously enough 20 years later the swing meter follows the exact same concept. Now that we got that out of the way let me start off by saying that the basics that make for a fun golf game and game play are present in this game. Whether or not you have some necessities to actually make your experience enjoyable is another question. You start off EXTREMELY hobbled. I was struggling to not get triple bogeys on every hole. The swing meter is VERY unforgiving and can get you very frustrated. As you go around and start playing rounds with random players you start to notice that other players do not seem to have as much trouble as you do. Then you notice they have certain clubs, buffs, accessories, enchantments. You start shopping around for these things and notice in order to get anything worthwhile you have to purchase them. Hey, no problem. I can do that. Then you notice there are two types of currency. Gold, which is in game currency you earn through matches and missions and the precious platinum which they give out to you in drips and drabs every once in a blue moon. The platinum is what you purchase with actual real money. the going price is $10 for 5000 platinum. I know what you are thinking. You are thinking, "Wow, I bet you can buy a lot of sh!t with that." WRONG! For example, there is a buff used when you putt that gives you a projected path of the ball. Trust me, this is almost mandatory when you get on some of these greens that are crooked as fk. They sell them by the 100 for guess what? 5000 platinum! The prices on this game are out of control. But nevertheless there is still alot of crap you can buy with the inhouse gold. One way to make a lot of in house gold is by using the challenge option. This is where they match you up against certain PVE computer players of different ranks. Depending on the rank of the player you can get a certain amount of gold for defeating that player. The only problem is you are only only allowed play three challenges a day and if you lose all three of them then you are sh!t out of luck. Not only do you not make any gold but it cost you money to enter these contests. So guess what happens when you go and try to play after you have expended your three limit challenge? Yep, you guessed it. You can circumvent the three limit by paying platinum currency. This game just oozes greed.  In my guesstimation you are probably looking at spending about $60 to really enjoy this game. Perhaps more down the line. You may say well $60 is not bad. Most triple AAA games cost that much. This ain't no Triple AAA game bruh. The graphics  are OK, I would say 7 outta 10. The optimization is absolutely TERRIBLE! It is common to drop to 14 FPS in town's square which ain't no big deal since that is not where the actual game play is. Its not acceptable but not a huge deal. But occaisonally you will get a drop like this in game play and that is fkn unacceptable. You are giving me 14 FPS with mediocre graphics set on medium and there ain't even 50 guys running around on screen like most MMOs? GTFO here! And you have the nerve to charge an arm and a leg for petty buffs and clubs? I cannot recommend this game even though I really wanna love it since I love golf games and as I mentioned the game play could be fun with the right equipment AND no frame rate drop. The frame rate drop is what caused me to down vote it. You cannot have a jumpy screen when trying to peg that swing meter. Impossible. As previously mentioned, without buffs just pegging the meter slightly to the left or right means means rough, bunker or even worse hazard or OB.I think if in a few months, they realize no one is playing any more and they decide to work on the graphics and for fks sake get that FPS to a minimum of 30 with a full server, then maybe it might be worth giving it a shot. I personally think they should A) fix the graphics, B) charge 15$ to actually buy the game and C) drop the P2W model entirely and go with p2p with charging for REALLY special packages but make most of the good clubs and buff accessible for reasonable in game currency. The game has potential to be really popular but as of now I cannot recommend.EDIT: As of today (11/16/2016) the putt guide buff is selling for 2500 platinum. Maybe they are starting to realize they are asking too much for stuff.EDIT2.0: As of today (11/26/2016) the game is STILL struggling with FPS drops to the point of making the game practically unplayable.EDIT3.0: After playing the game for a solid month and a half and no longer experiencing FPS drops or swing bar skipping I have changed my vote from No to Yes. The rest of my comments about the outrageous prices still stands though. Game is fun and with the main technical issues resolved it is now worth giving it a shot.

												Great fun.  Decent game engine and a few nice course designs (and some strange courses).If you can enjoy playing against yourself or against friends who don't spend loads of money on this then it is 100% possible to have a wonderful time without it costing you a penny.Randomisation as to whether it's a push or a pull when you don't hit the sweet spot (rather than predictable behaviour depending on which side you're on) brings an element of randomness into it that isn't there in, say, Tiger Woods - where you can shape your shots as you like.  With luck this will get changed in the future, but even if it doesn't this still has a decent feel to it.  Shots are taken with the tried and trusted three-click method (or two-click if you're putting) and it all works pretty well.Playing "special" shots uses up your stamina/mentality points which are regained between holes (but it's OK, you can buy them back with real money by getting energy drinks and giving them to your caddy to carry around - if you're not prepared to be careful planning when you use non-standard shots so as not to exhaust yourself) which is a limitation.  In the special shots category are things such as power shot to hit ten yards further, straight shot to narrow the error window, draw shot, fade shot, punch shot, backspin shot, and a few similar items.  You're limited in what you can use by a) which shots you've actually unlocked by improving your stats, and b) which shots you choose to equip before you start the round.  You only have a limited number of slots (more if you spend real money) much as you have a limited number of slots to carry extra equipment like stamina-replenishment items or longer range golfballs.Whether you feel the need to spend money to get fancy clothes and clubs, or to kit yourself out with snacks and energy drinks, will be a personal choice dependent upon what you're hoping to get out of the game and whether you want to be competitive in the global tour rankings.  The game is free to try though, and you'll be able to get many hours out of it without investing anything other than your time - which should leave you in a good position to decide whether this game is for you.  It's worth remember that you can turn the ridiculous "commentator" (and I use that label very loosely) off.  If you don't then you might end up starting to like it, which would be bad.If you enjoy golf then this is certainly worth a trial run.If you want a friendly round then give me a shout - you'll usually find me on channel 5 hanging out on the beach.

Posted: November 9, 2016
												I played this game fairly thoroughly for the last couple weeks and got to level 20, and started using the level 20 clubs set.  I have just uninstalled for the simple reason that I found no actual fun factor.  I tried the f2p model and when playing for free, you do get given some basic equipment but you need to spend up big to improve your gears and for simple consumables that make the game easier to play.  Whether this actually makes the game 'fun' you will have to ask someone who pays.   There are a couple mechanics that have just made the fustration factor finally outweigh any sense of satisfaction.  To do the best shot you need to hit the sweet spot on the swing bar, which after level 20, and with a pretty good gaming computer, I can hit about once in 20.  This is really frustrating..  There are specialist skills which make very small changes to you swings/hits so you feel like there is nothing worth aiming for in terms of skill development.  If anyone played Pangya, I just want to compare its swing bar mechanic - in pangya if you clicked the swing bar at the power you want, and then realized you were long or short, you just let the swing bar go back to the start and you can try again.  Not so with winning putt, once you select power you are stuck with it.  This is really frustrating.  What makes it worse is that you can experience an accidentally 'double click' on the swing bar, which is a reported glitch and basically your click registers at the incorrect spot and so, since you can't just let it reset, you tank the shot and ruin the hole.  Some of the courses are nicely designed as you'd expect and then others are so monumentally stupid in design, that again, causes nothing but frustrating to a point where I got today and thought ' why am I putting myself through this.  Its just not fun.'  Why bother - well Im not.  Im done.  Good Luck if you choose you give this a go, for the early quick levelling levels say 1-15, its okay, but thats now worn off for me.

												At the beginning, I really liked this game.  I really did.  The graphics, for being free, are amazing.  This game is MUCH better than Golf With Friends. It really is like a golf MMO.However, that loveliness is short lived.  The difficulty ramp is just obsurd.  Plain and simple.  You're given Missions (quests if that term is more your flavor) and completing those helps ramp your skills up.  Which is great! And then you "level up" to being a Junior Pro.  And this is where the game just takes a nose dive to awful.The amount of courses you can play where you feel viable are sorely limited.  If you're sub level 20, then you're pretty much in 2 courses.  So if you're good with playing those 2 repeatedly, then you may enjoy the game.  I don't and I do not.  The words "Very Easy" are sort of a slap in the face because ALL courses can be labeled as "Very Easy" but their not.  You'd be lucky to escape each hole with a Bogey.  So you try again and again.  But the courses get harder and harder, the greens get steeper and tougher, WAY too quickly.  There is no easing into the higher end portions of this game.  Just a pure hard slap in the face and get ready to eat more bogeys than an Air Force Veteran...because that is all your diet will consist of.  The bonus of having power up items ("potions") and enchanting, yes you heard me right, enchanting your clubs to get bonuses are great...until you realize how utterly useless each of them are. I wanted to like this game, but when I'm consistently getting bogey and double bogey unless I play 2 certain courses, then I'm out.  I'd ask for a refund if I paid anything towards this...which I haven't.This is Dark Souls + Golf Because Bandai Namco hates you all.3/10 for scenery alone.

												I like that it's free, thumbs up for that. I dislike all the enchanting faff and gimmicks. These just get in the way of an otherwise good golf game. I hate the "stamina"  and "mentality" meters which often ruin an otherwise good round of golf. I hate that players with more money have better clubs which hit the ball further, and suffer less with stamina than newer players.There's so much tacky rubbish you must buy and mess around with, like hard boiled eggs, stamina drinks, training levels, golf bags with enough "slots" and endless other junk. It's like they weren't confident they had a good golf game so they added all this distracting junk which just makes it annoying. A lot of it is still confusing and I don't know what the purpose of it is. I also hate that you need to repair your clubs after every round. Yet with all these annoyances, I keep going back because playing online is still quite fun as you get better at playing. I will eventually get sick of the distractions though. I wish there was a version of this game where everyone had access to the same golf clubs, same everything, so it just came down to making a good shot.
